text: @katgleason Teams are not as resilient as founders. Some folks can be but they are more easily motivated by momentum—there's high variance in one's optimism. You need both though I think.

When building a startup:

If you have fear, de-risk by talking to users.
If you have uncertainty, build a prototype to rapidly rebuild your conviction.
If you have sudden doubt, sleep. Try again tomorrow.

text: @FurqanR No - I don't think users would stand to use 1000s of browsers but they might use 2-3.

For example, the browser is a single product made for 1 billion people—it does not segment itself in a way for large markets the way most consumer products do. In contrast, video has: TikTok, Twitch, YouTube, etc. Payments has: Stripe, PayPal, Square, etc. Even OS' segment now!

text: @fesja Of course, I thought that goes without saying—talk to users! You cannot answer the nuance of every subtle product decision though and you cannot robotically survey users constantly. At some point, you have to rely on intuition and the art of building product.

To clarify, I don't think you should go out and force all your employees to be users. For example, it was really challenging to get all our employees at MP to use the product organically.

I think there's a strict advantage when it is the case though.
@seancoleman86 Documenting is orthogonal from rapid execution and autonomy—generally speaking, I agree.
We want pretty graphs & integration with PagerDuty—we wouldn't want to build anything ideally. Not a core advantage for us.
@buckymoore @opstrace @sebp He knows where to find me if it's the right product for the job.
Per VM pricing per month is a deal breaker for us—we might have millions of VMs.
@milesward Most servers are not GCP

What is the best tool for a startup to use for early dev ops monitoring?

We care about things like disk utilization, CPU utilization, etc. across VMs. We're using GCP.

We also might care about logging stats like FPS across users but that is secondary.

text: @bbhart_ca @MightyApp I suspect it's incredibly important otherwise humans are just pixels in a window. I bet we all would've met up several times by now if it weren't for COVID.

@SirSlaw_ @MightyApp One way is we have a scheduled but optional meeting called "Braindump" that has absolutely no structure. You show up, you chat about problems, dream about ideas, or just work on stuff while people are talking. I think 80% of braindumps have led to a new or interesting insight.

After building @MightyApp remotely, fully distributed and have had a 300+ person company with physical HQs globally, I would *never* go back to a physical HQ again. The benefits are immense. You can hack serendipitous conversations fairly easily.

This is the way.

Send me mail! Wheeeeee:

Mighty Computing, Inc
548 Market St
PMB 96342
San Francisco, California 94104-5401 US
Setup on https://t.co/EfXX5gVsCh -- thanks folks!
@Austen What is this magic!?

I've been asked numerous times where our company's "HQ" is by various institutions. Each time I've answered: "Uh, we're remotely distributed but I guess if you need something...San Francisco?"

@nateparrott It's all about tap / click area width for error.

text:
@leohoxyz @MightyApp We suspect virtualization largely can handle the rebalancing but, in effect, yes. You get compute the moment you need it.

We admittedly have a lot to learn in this area. It’s a weak point I want to make very strong.

Later tonight every user will get 4x the compute capacity jumping Chrome to run on 16 vCPUs. They don’t have to do anything. It just occurs like making a website better. @MightyApp will be smooth with 50+ tabs.

A similar thing will occur in Jan upon upgrading all the processors.
This PSA was co-written by my wife who reminded me once again just as she has every year.
PSA for founders: do not be sad when all your numbers fall off between now and the first week of Jan. This is the lowest traffic for most products in the year. Enjoy your holiday time :)

@dividebyzerovc @garrytan @faraz_r_khan I think it will be. Games are a tremendous market and it’s not terribly hard for me to see what could come next. There are games I dream about that are only possible with game streaming. We will see who executes the best though.
Every now and then, while working away and playing a little you discover a great breakthrough. Today was that day. I can’t wait to show you. I can hardly go to sleep with excitement. Goodnight! 🌙

My friend @faraz_r_khan had a great point today: there are some startups where if you simply made a quick MVP of the product, it would be absolute garbage (game streaming) but if you make 300+ optimizations and carefully grind at it, you'll make something truly incredible.

@santoshc123 What’s wrong with it? 

Note: We have no intention to compete in this space but I am curious nonetheless.
Do you use the video call or voice call feature of Slack?
@mtata55 @amasad @paulg @replit @MightyApp We’ll help each other to make a great web. I’ll do what I can to make their product go beyond what’s possible today with browsers.
@tannerxjackson I feel you
@bytingtheapple @mau_rs Yes sir!
@mau_rs One time a user asked for us to throw in an MP plan as part of the sublease of our previous office.
@lmay Yeesh, after a decade of it being back to back, I am still in recovery through next year!

Version 60 went out tonight. The release before the release to begin new user onboarding again. Still on track!

Seeing some yucky artifacts randomly that will hopefully get fixed next release making the major refactor of the capture pipeline go stable. https://t.co/vSGeeAA91T
@craftyc0der It's a video stream
@juberti Congrats to you all!
@_anishagnihotri Ah, I think you got beat by 8 minutes: https://t.co/eKdxGPs30B

@xcoatl Keep in mind: the browser just provides secure access to the primitives of OS-level APIs. The only reason Meet isn't better than Zoom is because we're not moving fast enough on web standards & providing more control. It's completely solvable. A decade ago, Meet was non-viable.

@dankamel We have a lot of ideas and people have explored this area quite deeply—it's very hard. I suspect it requires breaking the constraints of what we know in terms of UX in the browser. 

We have an idea we're working on early next year. It will doubly solve the "Slack is slow" issue.

This is a giant list of ideas to fund (sans Electron apps) that will ultimately be displaced by the browser and could theoretically be augmented by multiplayer mode or the like. https://t.co/jza1zTbj0k
Whoever is first + has good quality wins
@discordianfish We will definitely target Slack soon but the webcam/mic support makes it out of scope for what we're releasing in the next month or so.
If anyone is willing to compile this list, aggregate it, and help me see the top N ranked, I will give you $100 or Mighty for free for a year (assuming you're in the right geo) — your choice.
We are in the early days but early conversations help me shape the direction—I know we have a lot to prove:🐎🛒
@andypeepo No - I believe desktop software will be largely displaced by web applications. There's no need to invest further.

Increasingly, I've been getting more and more founders & developers reaching out about something they think Mighty could solve for them to make a certain product possible. If you have ideas, please DM me. I am always interested.

The possibilities are endless.

text: Excited to see founders announcing new ambitious companies: everything from cheaper infra in space to search engines to take on Google. In a period flush with money, it’s a golden era to work on hard & audacious problems. I encourage founders to not just play it safe!
@faraz_r_khan Ikr!
@faraz_r_khan It’s still no 3ms!
@JonathanDrake @MightyApp We fork Chrome so we can kinda just add ourselves.
@faraz_r_khan Yeesh. That's local?
@harrybryars Yes! You could even change entire computers and you'd see your browser in the same state you left it.
@harrybryars Mighty would replace that. We are virtually a no input lag RDP.
Not that this is a perfectly conclusive test but it sorta shows you the difference locally (left) vs remotely (right). I am using the same DNS nameserver in both places: https://t.co/fx2wcyqNI7
@Ishfillet It ships weekly in closed beta.
This is a small example of how you can make browsers automatically better for everyone that would be particularly tricky without streaming them from the cloud.

Today I discovered that we can get DNS resolution times to be consistently 3ms vs 13ms. I thought 13ms was quite good compared to what people get locally (20-50ms) on their laptops but, wow, 3ms on every request!?

Tomorrow, when we ship, all of our users will just "get it."
@zebulgar @vardaspace @foundersfund @Lux_Capital @fiftyyears @tonsing @naval @Justin_Mateen Sounds like the kind of company I would've alternatively started. I am excited for you!
@DotProto Oh, this is the best part of the launch if you ask me!
@DotProto Great work, Simeon. Happy to send you feedback when you're ready after we've poked around.
@migsy_boy Completely different goals.
I think people are underestimating how big Cloudflare is going to be. Their pace is inspiring to me.
@patio11 @kevinakwok It’ll be far less shares.

@patio11 @kevinakwok That’s still quite late I think. Depending on the valuation, it now requires quite a bit of cash from your family. I am not sure I was going to ask my parents for $10K—that would only heighten the pressure.
@idforgood You spent a little bit of money and the shares are worth nothing in the end.
@patio11 @kevinakwok That requires quite a bit of foresight especially if it’s your first time.
@wisepanda5 Common stock early on is priced much lower because it is a riskier asset to hold relative to preferred stock. And therefore it has much lower FMV.
@kandarpddave I doubt most founders realize it.
@croix @ikding At some point the stock becomes expensive to buy when a non-board level determination on the FMV gets made. It really depends. Could be fine below $100m.
@giladrom When it’s hundreds of millions of dollars, these will be well orchestrated events. A year is a tiny amount of time per the benefit.
@letsfixtheworld I’d recommend deleting this since it’s going to confuse people.
@rkhanna Low thousands even at 5%! It’s ridiculously low.

@maxkolysh The gift tax has a max limit and you can gift whatever is under it, I believe, based on the FMV. So, ideally as soon as possible but realistically before the co is worth more than $50M and right before the next fundraise.
@rkhanna What are you talking about? The options are only hundreds of dollars most of the time that early on. I’ll pay for the stock myself for my team if they can’t afford it. Yeesh!
@thearjunmad Lower taxes owed.
@JonathanDrake @paulg School of hard knocks.
How to ask the founders: “Hey, do you allow employees to early exercise? How much would it cost me based on the strike and FMV?”
PSA for founders: gift your parents a small % of your stock under the gift tax allowance esp if they live in a low income tax state. They’ll get the QSBS benefits.
@PayomDousti @ikding It varies widely
@grahammcbain A part of it
@Viruthagiri @thejozefwhite After the asset is granted.
@dbworku +1
@_shankarganesh Yes
@ikding When it’s less than a $50m valuation.
@thejozefwhite *early exercise* :)
PSA: If you are a *very* early employee, early exercise your shares when the company has a very low valuation, file your 83b, and enjoy that sweet QSBS.

text:
If you want to demoralize yourself: build a landing page, put it on Reddit, and watch the mods smack it down for self-promo while all the comments hate on you.

Just build it.
Stop overthinking it. Talk to users, build it, and see what happens! You cannot landing page test your way into a great product with a great market.

@ialexryan @anshublog @a2d2 That said, in the case of Mighty, we wouldn't want people to have temporary access to the host and steal long-lived tokens. 

"Hey, does my website work?" is a little more analogous for us.
@ialexryan @anshublog @a2d2 In fairness, the long-living tokens are stored client-side most of the time so that hack is possible regardless of short-lived ones.
@scotwingo Yeah, I understand it's value in the "I want to give you temporary access" but you'd also want to revoke it on-demand in that case usually so I think it's less practical.

I can buy that the best rationale for short-lived tokens is that there's a moment where the token gets hacked but not again and it would reduce your exposure in the case where you don't realize you're getting hacked.
@eyupitssam https://t.co/Tmqi5GAjbn
@goelrohan6 https://t.co/Tmqi5GAjbn
@arvindamirtaa 500ms less latency because we have to verify the short-lived ones client/host.
@anshublog @a2d2 What's a real-world scenario where I got a short-lived token but then couldn't get another one?
@arvindamirtaa If you found a way to get short-lived tokens and the company didn't patch the vuln, how would that stop the exposure? You could just keep getting short-lived tokens.

What is the best example of why one should use short lived auth tokens vs sending long-lived refresh tokens for authentication?

We're struggling to see a good reason to not use long-lived ones. If we got hacked, we'd just revoke them all regardless of short-lived vs long-lived.

If you can’t find any users for your idea often the first thing you can do to find some is be even more specific about the use-case it works best for. Do it even if it means the market is small because a small market is better than no market. You can often widen it later.

text: “The crucial feature of the initial market is that it exist. That may seem like an obvious point, but the lack of it is the biggest flaw in most startup ideas. There have to be some people who want what you're building right now [...] that they're willing to use it, bugs & all.” https://t.co/PkGfrTBOlP
The gist is: we found rendering bugs / instability issues with Chromium using Vulkan and we'd love to help fix it.

We're looking for someone who has deep expertise with Vulkan for a quick chat. A long-shot but ideally someone that has experience with the Vulkan rendering pipeline in Chromium.

If you know someone, please @ them or DM me. We'd be more than happy to pay for the help. Thank you!

entity.name: The Last Dance
entity.description: In the fall of 1997, Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls allowed a film crew to follow them as they went for their sixth NBA title in eight seasons. That resulted in a stunning portrait of one of the sport's most iconic athletes and a celebrated team. ``The Last Dance'' follows the Bulls' 1997-98 season from start to finish, while also covering the rest of the chapters in Jordan's remarkable career. The 10-part docuseries follows the Jordan timeline from when he was an emerging star on his high school team to becoming a worldwide marketing force and cultural figure. The series takes its name from a phrase coined by then-Bulls coach Phil Jackson, who knew that the season would likely be the final run for the core members of that 1990s Bulls dynasty.

text: Pitch decks, investor updates, board meetings, marketing launches & landing pages, or filling out a Y Combinator application are all moments where you're forced to distill down the essential. They may seem like a means to an end but they force you to clarify the end-state.
@AaronMNathan True
@garrytan E team not being remote is like a founder not using their own product every day to internalize the problems.
.@eroc upgraded us to 96 cores to compile Chromium: https://t.co/uKfidI47A1 https://t.co/CsPqMMKbHH
@Austen "Watch me at 1.5x speed" is my favorite thing to say with Loom videos.
@akothari Impressive!
@paulineherr This is dope Pauline.

For tackling hard problems, I think you need to be naive enough to try to solve them, clever enough to solve them expediently, optimistic enough to handle setbacks, open minded enough to hear someone else's solution, and persistent enough to try every path if necessary.

It's 2020 and customer support is still a huge advantage if you want it to be. Nobody is expecting the founder to respond at odd times of the day within a few minutes with a fix that turns around within a few days.

Easy way to build really loyal, happy users.
@Austen @RyanQualtrics It's good to have stretch goals
@KateClarkTweets No

text: If you're a startup founder but don't have a great idea to work on, it's also a great time to join to rapidly see a journey for your own sake should you desire to start a company later.

.@MightyApp is hiring one last engineer this year. Now is an optimal time to join: many major issues de-risked, a team of seven, looking to scale up early next year, lots of room to carve out your own area of responsibility.

Our job description is here: https://t.co/hCTXYtETDE
@sachinrekhi They'll even open things in Edge even if your default is Chrome from any Windows-based link in settings.
@oshimakesmusic You should share more, not less. It’s all great work Oshi.
@iamslick Rockets are too dangerous for adults to handle—you've got to start somewhere. Knowledge creates safety.
@russpage https://t.co/GUe3mT0LDL
@gbildson How? It lands back down with precision. Today’s equivalent land in a tree usually.

@paulg Once I saw this, my view changed on that: https://t.co/nQCkkAagdC

If you add Kerbel Space, imagine combining the two somehow.
s/reusable/could land for clarity
@acooray I wish I could edit my tweet to say land vs reusable.
@AnthonyCastrio @joebarnard I’ve been watching Joe for a while. Awaiting my future glee.
@areteNYCA They do? I haven’t seen any that land. Link?
@acooray Have you seen one that can land? I haven’t.
Imagine the glee people could feel when the model rocket lands back down with precision. Kids would get to “play Elon.”

If Elon made a model reusable rocket kids could assemble, blast off, and then tinker with later, I bet it’d inspire a lot more people over the long run to join the space race—one of his stated goals. A lot of adults would probably buy it too.

Most people strive to be first to market but another clever approach is being intentionally *delayed* to market. You let a few companies form, validate what the demand is like, discover big gaps unsolved, and you narrowly solve a different big problem vs the most competitive one.

text: @Kuehl The former
@yaseralkayale People took the question literally. I was trying to use the original as an example.

For many products, getting your users to delete the alternative, incumbent product is the final moment you know you've made it with that user. Products often cannot merely reach parity, they must be a lot better.

I like to ask: "What would it take for you to delete <y>?"
@PeteDram Exactly. Users win the most here and it's not particularly hard.
@PeteDram The cloud is far too expensive. For simple services we will use it for speed but otherwise it's untenable. We will likely build our own DC over the long-term.

Every startup has 3 major product problems it will think about over 10 years.

Mixpanel was: fast query performance, data visualization UX, inventing new metrics.

Mighty is: low latency network performance, hardware cost optimization, browser productivity.

What about you?

@sachinrekhi We are focused on speed not performance: loading a website, finding that document, rendering that website, getting into your next meeting, searching on Google faster.

We would not: make it easy to take notes, solve calendar availability, or do screen time for websites.
@Daudex There any many greatly skilled pessimists who are wonderful at poking holes in a nascent plan.
The best way to combat a pessimist is to have an optimist in the room who they respect.

@exdeve Not every day

@xoelipedes - Me giving the team a lot more autonomy
- Early team is self-managing
- More verbose / tighter communication—no crutches
- Permitting failure before scaling to “practice” being great
- Clear & narrow focus on 1 value prop for users: speed

@xoelipedes Momentum: are things growing, are some users happy, are you making some money—is it getting easier? Not every month will be a blockbuster but over a long arc it shouldn’t be flat-lined and sapping your energy. You should be gaining confidence and energy.

text: Most startup technical debt largely occurs as a function of "Let's do X and call it a day" because there's about 20 other stomach-churning reasons your company will probably die that need to be addressed first.

A big part of being a great engineer is the difference between "Ok, it works & I am done!" and "it works, I fixed the most common edge cases, I'm aware of more UX issues but lets put 'em in the backlog for now, lets ship—i know there's more work to make this great"

@scottbuscemi @patrickc Ah boo. That's not the sentiment here. Patrick cares here, I am ready for action, and I am willing to be led if he's got a plan.

Let's get going.
@patrickc Ok. Ok. What's Next?

@paulg Sometimes the banked cash is so much smaller than your payroll expense that you risk going sideways in a cataclysmic event. It might take a raise to bank the right ratio of liquid cash to monthly expense to de-risk death. A resourceful founder could prob figure it out tho.
I don't know what everyone is complaining about. It's like I woke up and now I can get in perfect night-time work flow. https://t.co/WjqqPMHg2u
@arvindeashwar We do! ⌘D (as in drive or doc) to access fast drive search.
@cwehrung The product is still maturing and it's not scale time yet. We'd give you it now but we know you'd probably go back to Chrome.
@vinayjain404 The simplest solution to most engineering perf problems: caching.
@mckaywrigley Keep a narrow focus until you win the market—your boredom is a trap.
@tarangp Unfortunately, we need around ~100 Mbps to deliver a decent experience.
@edzitron Your general location?
@TheRiverCard Charge a monthly subscription for a great browser that will become your super computer.
@tarangp How close are you to Sydney? What’s your bandwidth down?

text:
Things it needs:
- Less violent
- Co-op but teams can compete
- Voice chat
- Auth by Slack/Google
- < 45 min play times for quick turnarounds
- Hand/eye coordination independent
- Works on computers/mobile
- Encourages fun post-game chatting 
- Automated/randomized team balancing

The first B2B game is going to create a new category. It’ll have to be different than normal games though for it to succeed in work culture. Probably less individually  competitive and more co-op while scaling to 8-20 people. https://t.co/KAVI46h1AM

text: @myprasanna @elonmusk The trouble with emulating idols is that we're not as good as the idols. Most founders who tried to emulate Steve Jobs got themselves into a lot of trouble because copying something whole-sale doesn't capture the nuance/style of that leader's personality & prior success.

Depending on what you care about, it can be torturous to not chime in on a weird design, a UX idea that's confusing, or code oddly written w/o the future in mind but the most important thing isn't the day-to-day decision making anymore, it's your failure to design the right team.

In the long-run, it's more important to build a team that can quickly & autonomously get to the right decisions without blocking on you. You'll also seem far less like a micromanager too. Boy, did I fail at this on the first run. It all mattered, all the time. 😬

As your team grows, every founder that sweats the details will often feel compelled to jump in to offer feedback or help quickly solve a problem. It's been my experience that you should resist that urge at first because you'll learn what you're missing in the team that you value.

urls.description: Cron Cron is an app that shifts your Google Calendar into Pro Mode. Share specific time slots with people within email and messages in seconds. Time zone conversions. text: @ksimons Especially considering, 50%+ of your time is sitting in Chrome.

@pulpendicular You don't need a high Internet speed, you need low congestion. There's a reasonably strong correlation sometimes but not precisely.

60% of the US has 100 Mbps+, 2% has 1 Gbps. It's less competitive to build a company in the making. 100 Mbps has been perfectly fine.
@sachinrekhi @shl I am not seeing the problem. Sounds like a feature, Sachin.
@sachinrekhi @shl You cannot imagine a tasteful way this can be done w/o outing a specific company?

@arvindeashwar No — Chrome Books are bad: worse OS, similar price points, & a limited computer.

This is different: keep your computer, losing nothing, & our intent is to make a faster browser that, in time, will inevitably become your computer. Prices will freefall w/o a need to upgrade.

@johnmalatras - Slow logins because we're using a custom auth token in a node desktop app
- Janky to enforce unique constraints on the data model
- Not easy to get an audit trail on queries
- We have to recompile gRPC in our app which is a huge pain in the butt
- Weak internal admin tools

We're looking for a Firebase alternative to manage app/user-specific data. Leaning towards Django because of django-admin but is there something that's more managed?

Features we need:
- Low latency queries (replication across geos)
- Simple admin UI to manage data
- Simple db

@r2r You'll never know

@trupthi_s I find a large list weighs on me. The tiny things take up a lot of brain space just by the mere fact I must remember them. So, if I solve the tiny, easy things first then I have less stress & more focus when I tackle the bigger, hard thing.

How to keep the momentum while working hard:

- Don't burn out
- Pick fun projects 
- Don't be a single point of failure 
- Spread your knowledge
- Delegate
- Fire yourself from boring jobs
- Pair on projects, don't get stuck 
- Take staycations
- Solve the little problems first

11/ When you do something awesome, enjoy it. When you make a mistake, learn from it & move on. Have a few people close to you in the company that you can confide in. They will help you enjoy the hard times & remind you to learn from them.
10/ Make your environment as non-hierarchical as possible. People should not be dependent on you. Make an environment where anyone can step up if they see an opportunity to move the ball forward.

9/ While growing, you will constantly have to re-evaluate what you’re doing, why you’re doing it, & whether you’re having a positive impact. I did this by constantly comparing the beginning of each year to the previous.

text: 8/ Building a company isn't just about the product. It's about the users, team, investors, media, & partners. Making strategic decisions about what you prioritize can be the difference between a company that grows fast or one that stalls.
7/ As the company grows you will have to make many decisions that are not solely based on results. This is hard. Try to not fall into the trap of rationalizing based on who you know/are friends with.
6/ The great thing about having a board is they help you take your blinders off.

5/ Don't rush to try to fix every problem as they come up. Things take time to fix & it’s important to know when something really is broken and requires an overhaul. It’s also important to know when it’s a minor thing & you just need to know how to handle it in the short term.
4/ Get out of the building. You will learn everything you need to know about your customers by talking to them, spending time with them.
3/ I try & remember that I’m not an expert in everything. I’m not smarter than other people. I just work harder at what I love. Don't assume what you think is important will be important to others.

text:
@samehueasyou I love & use Stripe but one often isn't required to use Stripe to realize its full economic value. Whereas, it is largely required for a game to be on Windows or iOS.

I don't think Stripe is platform, yet.

Gates said something along the lines of, “That’s a crock of shit. This isn’t a platform. A platform is when the economic value of everybody that uses it, exceeds the value of the company that creates it. Then it’s a platform.”

Gates is King.

text: One reason you cannot easily part-time do a startup is that so many of the best, clever ideas occur somewhat spontaneously. You sort of look at all the possible angles over a span of 12-18 months and one day, while looking at a tree, the proverbial apple bonks you on head.
Nothing motivates an engineer more than trying to get their PR closed to avoid having to deal with someone elses merge conflict.
Waitlist-ware: Software announced to the public that sit behind a waitlist but have no intention of releasing any time soon, if ever.

text: @Ol_Wall @Austen Just have fun building something you think is cool—don't make it a career, make it a passion.
@Ol_Wall @Austen I picked up Visual Basic 6 and starting writing bots on battle net for fun in 7th grade.
@Austen I still don’t have one.

If you start a project, you’ll have more fun building it, you’ll probably make something you understand well or for yourself, and if it doesn’t go anywhere, nobody will judge you for it. You’ll probably avoid bad things people do when they start merely by focusing on the product.

If you fear starting a company because you’re worried you’ll waste your time or you’ll fail, don’t start a company. 

Start a project. 

It’s mostly the same thing for 12 months until you have employees, make money, and have users that rely on you every day.
@tonymarks__ Nope
@Mat_Sherman Once I get this feature, I’ll be my own podcast.

@Austen Also, wanna play GTFO with me? It’s amazing.
@Austen I feel like you’re ahead of me in the books I chose.

text:
Tons of products started by a few groups of users using it at the beginning: 

- Google was made for Stanford’s corpus first 
- Facebook was only for Harvard students 
- Slack dialed in making it work for a few mid-size companies first
- Heck, Uber started with Black car!
@Arthirty I wouldn’t want an email address anymore that I didn’t control.
@BenjaminGCox @garrytan @garrytan is king

It’s okay to launch your app with only a handful of invited users. Don’t let anyone pressure you into scaling because they think you’re being elitist—making a few people happy is critical at the beginning. When the product is great & everyone is using it, that noise won’t matter.

@sararahmcb You may be misunderstanding the launches. People have figured out that scaling an app early comes with a lot of distraction. Dialing the product in & deciding to scale up over time has major implications on user retention / focus for the founders.
@markpinc @joshelman @Nextdoor Absolute worst
@Austen x isn’t always true

@anandc I think you misunderstood my message.

Increasing the surface area of a product is the most subtle way companies move slower. That’s why it’s so important to be clear on what you’re willing to be great at & willing to cede to avoid the debt incurred by more features. So, experiment quickly & ruthlessly deprecate.

@parthi_logan I think you can discover the market size in 3 ways to de-risk things. This is what I've done: (1) is there an existing incumbent w/ a large user base?, (2) if you sell the dream, do a lot of people sign up for it (ie: waitlist), (3) research about its trend: growing or shrinking?

@youfoundanisha I think you can go and find another hill to climb every so often. In our case, we might make designers really happy but sales people might not be. So, we might climb that hill a little later when we have the resources.

@youfoundanisha For me, I'd always be looking at the spread of happiness. In other words: consistently making the happiest users happy (they're your beachhead) and making the users that are close to happy like the happiest. I would probably not prioritize the casual, semi-displeased.

Trying to make a 1000 people happy by chasing primarily the macro-set of issues among them all is a surefire way to make a mediocre product. A different approach is trying to make 10 people really happy then finding 990 people just like them.

urls.title: macOS 10.15: Slow by Design
urls.description: Programming, automation, algorithms, macOS, and more. In episode 379 of ATP both Marco Arment and John Siracusa described noticeable delays and stalls after upgrading to macOS 10.15. I have been struggling with this issue myself and have found several system operations that can cause these delays, which I will detail below. One way to solve the delays is to disable your internet connection. This is tough medicine, but if you notice these delays, try it for an hour just to verify that indeed the issue is

text:
Finally, real hard proof that Catalina is a major regression of Mojave: https://t.co/YD5LFcNHiF

I am not precisely sure who is running macOS at Apple but it's steadily becoming a Apple keyboard fiasco. Nobody on our dev team wants to upgrade after seeing so many user issues.

@rabois I am not passing a judgement on whether you *should* or *should not* do that. I am imploring those folks to search their own heart about what's right.

I personally agree with you & that's precisely how I handled it: including employees. Even those who had left.
@iambrainland Speed to term sheet & close is not a metric anyone will care about in the long-run. None of this obviates the hard work that comes next: building something people want.

@katgleason If someone buys $2m of your common, typically, you distribute the $2m in proceeds to all the common shareholders (including your employees). If there are no employees and the founders are 50/50, each takes $1m home.

If taking some money would be *life changing*, it's irrational to not take it. It's literally *life changing*.

I wouldn't let anyone's subjective sense of right/wrong, incentives aligned/not aligned make you feel bad. Make your own decision, in your own heart.

If a VC hands you $12M on $100M post plus a $2M in cash to buy your common, don't hate the player, hate the game. 

Focus on your craft instead focusing your energy on what others got that you don't.

More people, more time spent, more problems.
One of the earliest signs your product is getting better for users is that your job steadily shifts from building all day to doing customer support all day.

The simplest thing I've learned to do in business that has always paid dividends is paying people quickly with minimal fuss when they've held up their end of the bargain. 

One day turnarounds on invoices builds immense amounts of trust.

text: @andrewljohnson @benedictevans All attempts wherein apps like Figma, Slack, etc. exist outside the browser are trying to solve two major issues: (1) the web APIs to make something aren't available so they bridge using Electron and (2) users desire a focused app sometimes so the UX of the browser is ill-fitted.

@andrewljohnson @benedictevans The properties of the browser are too amazing to ignore: instant updates, code that works on all OS', a secure area to run arbitrary code, instant distribution, and a gigantic user base. I think the future of desktop apps remains in the browser--even the heavy ones.

@cloudyviolin We actually started out desiring to do that but two realities occurred: (1) Windows has absurd licensing fees for virtualization, (2) The long-tail of desktop, native apps is shrinking, and (3) the browser is where we increasingly spend most of our time.

The browser is the OS.
@satish_vutukuru It's precisely whatever you set at the OS level. We get x/y values at whatever speed you're moving the mouse and simulate it back to the host.

text: @BeardAintWeird_ Not really - web APIs only took us so far initially. In order to get pixel-accurate scroll deltas we had to simulate the ticks on a virtual device using an X11 input device driver on Linux.

@benedictevans Great thought - the issue is that the UI / rendering is what takes up a lot of RAM and CPU causing the bloat we see client-side.

In my opinion, the goal of browsers was precisely that: a thin way to access data remotely.

The most surprisingly hard thing about making a streaming browser is how hard scrolling is to get perfectly right. You have to dial in the momentum, how far it goes per wheel click, support magic mouse vs regular vs trackpad, iframes vs non-iframes, etc. Users are very sensitive.
@manan19 @BuckleyBarlow We are still developing it and it's not quite ready for prime time. Testing it with only 10-20 users rn. Just sign up on the website.
@ernestoschez which?

text: @immad I don't think a startup could do that w/o risk of being copied by an incumbent (IGTV did to video). Odds of success seem higher by being a destination for a specific kind content w/ the biggest market & owning that mindshare. It would be hard for an incumbent to brand vertically.

@immad So, it's a race right now to find out which vertical is going to be most sticky & a huge market. 

My best guess is comedy/music vs podcast style intellectual content. The creators in the former are craving a way to monetize their audience & the audience is much larger.
@immad I think Clubhouse is https://t.co/Gk69N0gm5F for audio wherein it has yet to find its Twitch vertical vs a net-new X for Y.

Asking your smart friend how they'd compete with you is a more engaging way to get better feedback than asking: "So, what do you think of my idea?" Instead of someone possibly hurting your feelings, the other person gets to generate many ideas that you can use later.

text: Which kind of browser user are you? https://t.co/RRgcAmgaA4
@mmay3r We're going to do that. We'll probably go one step further and have a CDN right next to the machine constantly caching so it makes fewer hops seeking info.
@ndrewlee I will help you one day...

@StefaniaBje The 3 major personas I've discovered:

- Single window warriors: Type A people who never let their tab count grow beyond 20.
- Chaos the organized: 1-2 windows, 40+ tabs but they know where everything is.
- The context-switcher: Many windows w/ many tabs. Interrupt driven. Chaos.
@adityadpandey But there's always a gem or two in the 80% that make it so it could be days before they get closed.
@WhiskeyGary69 I make no judgments. Organized chaos is a valid way to live life.
@JoshuaLelon The human mind is incredible.

> Please tell us something surprising or amusing that one of you has discovered.

Looking at and going through a person's browser windows and tabs has to be the fastest approximation you can get to understanding how a person's mind organizes.
@danielgross Superhuman's inbox zero background. In order to see it, you must first have achieved victory over your inbox. The user and software celebrate together.

It’s not hard to imagine a world where you go to an office for social events but stay at home to focus & work after this. 

Onsites become offsites.

text:
@sriramk There are two common scenarios with investors: 

(1) 1:1 first chat 
(2) mtg the partnership

I find it’s easy to read the room with (1) with video and really hard to read the room with (2) once N is greater than 4 even in-person.
@toddg777 Glad to hear it’s better for you too.
@orienwu Nice clicktey clacktey. I cannot get that wife approved.
@orienwu 😎

Investor meetings are 5x more efficient through video for founders: 

(1) No commute to the meeting
(2) Easy to demo product 
(3) Get right back to work in flow
(4) Easy to show any materials based on flow of conversation
(5) Work while you wait vs sitting in a lobby

@RJShupak @DCoolican They'll approximate except in situations where the reason would gravely offend the founders. For example, you and your co-founder seem like bad fits together, you're socially difficult to deal with, or you didn't seem on top of things. Those reasons are often closely held.

Asking your employees  "What do you suspect the reason we will fail will be?" is extremely valuable too. They have all the inside knowledge. Makes for a great 1:1 too to unearth major issues. If you can, especially ask the employees leaving the company as well.

text:
My favorite question to ask investors at the end of a pitch is: "What do you suspect the reason we will fail will be?"

Benefits:
(1) You get *some* feedback (don't be defensive)
(2) You can learn if they know something you don't
(3) Counter-interview - are they smart too?

text:
I learned a bit of React yesterday. Got to building something simple with React hooks today. CSS tomorrow. :)

Useful post of the day was this: https://t.co/tJEmKvcDHP

@curioustalwar I am just picking various ideas to build based on the projects available & where I can chip in with the team. Sometimes it's greedy & for fun, other times it's pragmatic and necessary.

It's easy to get wound up & forget I *get* to have fun doing this.

Every now & then it’s valuable to build something from the ground up again: you get to see what’s newly possible, you develop empathy for how subtle, complex it is to accomplish, and you get to see how the pieces could fit together in a better way than before.

v0.0.24 will have audio support. Finally. #1 requested feature.

I am working on some new UX stuff for browsers that doesn’t exist. Having so much fun creating again this past year.

@paulg I’ve always thought of Jobs’ “Hey Jony, here’s a dopey idea...” as almost a primer that idea will be bad but it’s fragile because most ideas, spoken, seem kind of silly. 

I like your version of the question because it’s in pursuit to strengthen the idea vs a trite dismissal.

On ideas:

"Why hasn't anyone done that?" is one of the best ways to kill the momentum of a fragile idea.

"Has anyone done that idea really well?" is a better way to contribute & make it stronger.

23/ "Q: Would you recommend sharing company financials at an early stage with the team, in the interest of transparency? (ARR, months till death, cash in the bank)"

Me: 100% - yes! I wouldn't emphasize looming death every week though - maybe a tactful monthly mention.
I've had three designers tell me their major clients canceled huge projects, aren't paying invoices on time, and have very few clients available now.

Behind the scenes, unbeknownst to most people, there's a total wipeout of freelance contractors either about to happen but certainly steadily happening.

If you employ these individuals, please be kind in a moment of crisis.

22/ Believe me, things can get worse: I raised $500K @ 25% dilution  (excluding YC's 7%) in 2008 after 10+ "no's" two weeks away from imminent death. Hat in hand, we would've gone back to AZ. Times are different now and the bar will still be higher but it can get much lower too.

text: 11/ Unexpected times create new constraints for everyone. More than ever, it's a great time to start companies that seemingly make everyone hyper-aware of the situation they're in. Should you help people save money? have fun indoors? learn differently? will video feel less awk?

10/ One little trick I used to keep expenses at bay was to call in my credit card for fraud every 6 months. It was annoying to re-add it to services I actually used but it guaranteed cutting recurring expenses I wasn’t thinking about anymore without analysis.
@immad i texted you
Thought of a huge, easy to build feature after 10 mo of thinking about deeply about browsers. Desperately must temper my desire to build it to stay focused & wait my turn.
@Austen No way Italy is the only major hit.
@Austen Holy hell. This feels like it’s going to be worse than 2008-2009.
506 minutes

9/ It's time to get lean & scrappy culturally. Being lean means removing expenses that are unnecessary. The right employees don't care about free Kombucha. Being scrappy means finding clever solutions to otherwise difficult, time costly, or expensive options.

8/ It's never been more important than right now to be honest with your team around burn rate, odds of success, areas to focus, etc. The folks who stick around will appreciate it & work hard. Some others might move to more stable pastures--that's fine. It's all hands on deck.

7/ Expect investor decision making to take longer if things worsen. I’ve talked to many founders waiting till they had 2-3 months of runway. This correction will feel surprising & create unnecessary stress so plan ahead. Due diligence will get more intense—have the numbers ready.

6/ In 2011, we went out to raise our Series A. Things had calmed down for seed but we quickly got passed on by 11 VCs. We were doing $45K/mo which grew to $190K a year later. We were forced to raise bridge that barely came together. There’s no shame in this. Raise what you need.

text: It’s RIP good times meets the corona virus
Wow @ this Sequoia memo that just dropped. Founders about to learn the survival skills of ‘09.
@Austen Shared 1-3 person office & home.

6/ You can ship more quickly by maximizing autonomy & building a culture of prioritization by persuasion. Meaning, allow people to choose their work based on their mood, life, & interests. Use persuasion & team dynamics to get certain things done. Often they'll work harder.

5/ Product is a combination of art & science. Too much data-driven focused product development leaves a product that lacks soul & often delight. So, you'll have to practice building good judgment. If you don't have it, try to get as far as you can validating something w/o code.

4/ To ship product fast, you must scope just enough. That means you'll have to use judgment. I find that most of the time being greedy early on & satisfying the simple use-case is usually correct. Waiting & seeing how badly people want the rest is usually obvious later.

3/ Being picky means eliminating users you aspire to serve. A simple strategy is eliminating people who don't have severe pain for the thing you're solving. Once you've whittled them down, you can go further: eliminate users by the features they want that you don't have yet.

2/ To talk constantly with users, I find befriending your users is the simplest strategy. Once your friends, they won't mind you bugging them for feedback constantly. At some point, you'll text/DM instead of email/schedule video chats which have high activation energy.

text: Two important vectors to build momentum in a startup are listening to users & shipping speed. To listen well, you'll need to constantly talk to users & be picky about who to serve. To ship quickly, you have to scope just enough & have good instincts about how to solve the problem

@yenFTW It’s merely a function of time allocation. No time spent on experimenting is too greedy. I tend not to wander into other ventures that could be entire companies & focus around a single pain point. For us, it’s speed, efficiency, productivity. Pain can be attacked from angles.

Next month we finally get to begin to differentiate from Chrome by building things that simply don’t exist but should for the sake of speed & productivity. Exploring lots of new ideas, designs, and experiments — it’s so fun to get to be this creative again.

text: @khaledealy There are features and then there mega-features that look new business lines or products. Like YouTube getting into live-streaming—that can be really distracting/unfocused for a startup after product market fit.

Post product-market fit product strategy:

- Double down on what works
- Deprecate non-core features to reduce surface area
- If it’s valuable, measure & optimize it 
- Remove your ego & copy great ideas if they help your users 
- Don’t get distracted by building net-new products

@eshear +1 same lessons at MP. Often it’s better to dump the worst parts that users don’t use too. Usually they’re the worst for specifically that reason. Reducing surface area increases rate of improvement.

👏👏👏

If you need to rebuild a core piece of tech from scratch to make it possible, do it!

If you need to make some landmark deals happen, will it into existence.

If you need to tediously labor to accomplish something that doesn't scale well, grind through it.
Compromise is closer to giving up because the solution offers something obviously attainable/discoverable by others that leads to mediocrity. It’s better to break through the proverbial wall.

This second time around starting a company I cannot emphasize enough how critical merely being persistent at attacking unknowns/obstacles is to seeing the kind of momentum & success you wish to see in the world. The outcome is often binary because you either give up or discover.

11/ I hope you had fun *reading* 😉 Fin.

10/ The nice thing about reading culture is it requires more present, focused, and uninterrupted listening of another person's ideas. It's like an audio compressor for people who are near silent & an audio limiter for people who are typically more vocal--an equalizing force.

9/ The best way to get someone on the team who isn't very good at reading is to get them to be someone who gets to write down ideas at first. Sharing your ideas is fun & gratifying! However, eventually, they must read everyone's ideas about their ideas via comments.

8/ A sure fire way to fail at building a read culture: expecting everyone to read ahead of time. While a reasonable request, practically someone misses out. This creates steady dysfunction as the penalty is harsh for a possible crucial team member who should be in the know.
7/ If you want a better reading culture, write as concisely as possible to further reward reading. It will benefit your verbal communication of ideas as a by product too.

6/ Once people get used to reading & writing a lot, the culture eventually converges towards being memory focused. Stumbled upon some useful research? Write it down for the person who may tackle it. Ambient context begins to grow about all problems & ideas to speed up progress.

5/ Often mtgs that begin w/ writing & a pre-read aren't just shorter, they're more in-depth. This is much harder to accomplish in a traditional presentation format wherein participants either can't interrupt or can't get the full picture until it's presented. Less collaboration.

4/ Written ideas ahead of a meeting, a 10 min pre-read at the beginning of a mtg, & commenting as people read through a doc have led to far more engaging meetings for me. Ledes are not buried. There's more time to square the details. Ideas that have consensus are skipped.

3/ If you want a good company writing culture, it's critical to give time to folks to read. Usually it's better at the beginning of the meeting--people rarely read before. Also, early attendees can get a head start w/o waiting on folks that are late. Possibly an advantage too!

The area it's easiest to lie to myself is thinking something is sufficiently painful. Maybe it is for me or maybe I just want to believe it is so badly. To mitigate: employ a series of harsh tests where users give you something (money, time, energy) to prove its pain.

@akothari I hope this is obvious but just in case it’s not: founders should sell the first 100+ customers. Then you’ll know what’s a realistic sales plan for your future reps & you can be confident it’s achievable. I sold & onboarded the first 300 customers on my own.

I wrote a mini thread on scaling early bottoms sales teams (specifically around quotas) after many years of trying, failing, and seeing fairly reasonable success. I think our first $30-40M was mostly all small customers initially: https://t.co/W7nF4syetr
@arsalanbashir @willmegson @mixpanel @momarkhan Wfm

@akothari It’s generally typical to comp 50/50 base/OTE. Start with a quota that’s ~3x OTE with the goal of getting to a 4-5x multiple, pay on revenue not units, make quota payouts linear early on, a simple accelerator that’s achievable, tweak every 6 mo, one quarter of quota relief.
@arsalanbashir @willmegson @mixpanel @momarkhan A social/formal commitment to your future team.

@willmegson @mixpanel @momarkhan mighty_head_count++;

(first official hire 🎉)

@akothari If you royally fuck up the sales plan, do the right thing and true-up your sales people for going along with you on the crazy bumpy ride of everyone learning for the first time together. It may take a few quarters of true-ups to get everyone comfortable.

@akothari Sales plans need real buy-in from the sales people. They have to believe in the quota/plan. Yes, it will feel odd to ask someone if they're okay with a "goal" they are incentivized to minimize but the conversation is not usually as misaligned as you'd think.

text: @akothari Build an extremely strong Sales Ops function (analyzes how it's all going) and Product Marketing function (gives ammo + supports the sales team needs) in tandem with building the sales org. Without it, you're blind and they're blind leading to lots of dysfunction. (Sorry team!)

@akothari If you're just starting out, make sales quotas sales people can easily overachieve on. That will help your sales people build both confidence & help you hire better sales people as word spreads that you can make $$$ at your company. Then, steadily optimize for sales productivity.

@akothari A decision around contract length is important as part of the quota: is it okay to get paid on monthly or annual contracts? For bottom's up sales, there's a natural tension between monthly and annual because those users like monthly but churn far less if the plan was annual.

@akothari Customers as a result of bottom's up sales are usually more churn-y than say larger, more established customers. You'll have to decide whether churn is a component of the sales quota. Usually, it's a bad idea to incorporate churn (or things sales has little control over).

@akothari Nailing a comp plan is extremely hard. Expect to change it many times over many years. You'll constantly be seeking for ways to align incentives perfectly but that will never exists. Perfect is the enemy of good.

@akothari Perhaps the most useful tip I could share, though strictly based on my narrow experience, that I wish someone told me: start very small, scale steadily not rapidly, and make sure 70% of the sales force is hitting 70% of its quota. Scale hiring behind potential but take some risk.
@akothari Too many to tweet. A lot of it will be hard-earned in spite of book, blogs, and experienced executives you bring on board.
@st_yoni Be curious instead of judging, reprimanding, and trying to be right. Assume you are incorrect to discover what you may be missing.

text: @dcurtis I used to think folks were a bit too financially motivated too but I’ve found, especially going through the last YC batch, people were just as friendly, hard working, and excited as 2009. They might order Postmates a bit too much now though...

I am pretty impressed by the primitives of Media Source Extensions for audio decoding/playback—we’ve come a long way with browsers. The SourceBuffer API can be greatly improved so if there’s someone out there, I’ve got some feedback to hopefully make it great—I think.
@OthmanAba Yes. Specifically in part due to: https://t.co/SAYW8hyjek
A little hack for me that worked was to feed the creative energy going a bit unfulfilled with a side project (not programming) & persevere through the immensely critical product grind ahead.

This was probably the hardest for me when things were growing incredibly fast (like 280% growth in a year) because I was always interested in the next big thing we could do. But almost always the better decision was to just stay the course & build a huge lead.
@nrose Well, I think it’s important to know the 100 little things will be worth the energy so it applies more to a situation where people want & have shown they want your product.

I’ve learned to never underestimate the power of 100 little improvements that could be potentially boring to build & unsexy compared to one, large net-new risky feature. Over a long run, those 100 little things make companies appear far more innovative & make a huge impact.

@sachinrekhi Master plan:

- Fund a long-term study that matters to Indian people 
- Build a significant marketing campaign to change the narrative
- Ensure doctors are informed & taught new defaults
- While doing so, raise more money to fund new kinds of research targeted @ ~Indian men/women

@trq212 The worst case is bankruptcy & the debts being paid by you.

@immad My point is that you can lower your valuation & the amount but not 1:1.

The desire of greater runway is two-fold: (1) Cost control - you don't need to increase burn just because you have the money & (2) Can you realistically grow faster per $1 spent or should you bide your time?

When investor demand is high, most founders choose to raise more money at a higher valuation with the same % dilution. You could raise less money (just what you need) at a lower valuation w/ less dilution. Then you have a lower pref stack + easier time growing into your valuation

@sama I remember wanting to raise a Series A round ($3-4M at the time). Of course, I failed. So, we took a bridge round of $1.25M to not appear like total failures. In the end, we had 75% of the money left by the time the next Series A occurred 2+ years later--only gave up 10% vs 20%.

@sama Conversely: don't artificially increase your valuation just to reduce dilution. Just raise what you need with a small buffer if you're wrong. Then, get scrappy.

Back in '09, we had fewer funding options & leverage but because we raised so little we all had to be disciplined.

text: @willmegson @mixpanel My new soon-to-be favorite Mighty feature coming: if chrome crashes, your computer restarts, or anything bad messes up your flow, Mighty will bring back up all windows w/ their respective tabs to all the correct displays in the prior width/height in the precise x/y position.
@zebulgar But, at least, product improvements often scale linearly & instantly in software.

@zebulgar Less obvious: value is a moving target. As time goes on, a $30/mo product must keep up w/ the world. If you don't keep adding value, it won't compete. Eventually, all technology becomes obsolete. So, there's a function of additional improvement required to keep the base price.

@zebulgar A simple test I use to often refute that price will give you a linear scaling advantage is asking myself: "If I made this $0, would I quickly increase the number of users by 10x?" Often the answer is a fractional versus multiplicative improvement.

@jamesbeshara @ajaymehta @joshuareeves @immad Next round, my man. It's still very early innings. Nobody has missed out :)

text:
@kevingibbon Founders will want to impress their most helpful investors. The pressure will be significant. It was that way for me. 

Many founders choose investors that they perceive as mentors. I think great mentorship can’t be devoid of psychological management.

Every founder I’ve met is going through their own existential crisis: growth is stalling, employees are leaving, they don’t think they’re a good CEO, unsure they’ll reach product market fit, culture is changing too quickly

If you’re not hearing it, that’s an opportunity to help.

text: @faraz_r_khan The trap is thinking it’s selfish imo. It’s hard enough to build a startup as-is but the odds are further stacked (1) when you can’t relate to your users, (2) you often won’t use the product to make it better, and (3) you can’t easily accumulate instincts about the market.

My personal litmus test for founder market fit is if I stay up late (2 AM) to hack on the idea 6 months later. Not because you must, though often raw hours matter early on, but because you’re having so much fun building & obsessing over the product.

text:
I made:

- A MySpace parody called MyEnemies (2006)
- A curated RSS feed of tech stuff to rival Digg (2007)
- A Wikipedia for opinions (like Quora) (2008)
- A lot of facebook apps (2008)
- A Zynga-style game (2009)

They all failed.

It's *normal* that founders have usually built 4-5 complete failures (often each taking 6-12 mo each) before "haphazardly stumbling" across an idea that finally works.

A music artist is often nearing a thousand "okay" songs before they make a song that gets 1M plays.

@akaushik759 You can watch it live & vulnerable: https://t.co/29LAezmCtJ

Subject to catastrophic failure.

When we see the final work of a builder or an artist, we are often seeing the final results. Masked are the things thrown away or hidden because they weren’t proud of it. The inspiration we feel with the final work often lacks the perspective & discipline it takes to get there.
@willmegson Little things eventually manifest their way into culturally important, big things later: https://t.co/LjokiVl0pt
@jmj It's advised every batch. Ignored by some largely to their own peril & regret.

Copying precisely is often harder & less successful than emulating the principles & executing in your own style.

Applies to product design, leadership, writing songs, etc.

text:
Looking to do audio capture on Linux. Currently reading about ALSA. Are there any better/faster ways to do audio capture? 

Cannot just use web apis for this.

8/ Lastly, try to find enjoyable & challenging activities that can create complementary contention. For example, when I can't write new music, it makes me want to write code because it seems easier so I procrastinate. When programming becomes hard, I finally want to write music.

7/ For the "distracting, a lot of time" category, "change the defaults" in your life:

- Turn off push notifications
- Have your phone on default Do-not-disturb
- Hide the dock on macOS to increase focus
- Greyscale your phone screen color
- Delete the app
- Log out after use

6/ If you find yourself without motivation to tackle "important, little time" tasks, then build a repository of "relaxing, little time" activities instead. It will help you gain new energy & motivation later. This is where I also need to improve the most & generate more ideas.

5/ For activities that are "Important, a lot of time", I'd schedule an actual day or half a day block to give myself the appropriate time & patience (morning is best for me) to achieve them. Scheduling is critical to let people know so they can support your day of focus.

4/ For the "A lot of time, Not very important" activities in your life, the goal is to regulate them. So with email, for example, you'd do it 2 times a day (morning, evening) for an hour vs throughout the day. You should control it vs letting *it* control you.

3/ When I get bored & have a little spare time, I now try to prioritize all the things in "Little time" by importance before allowing myself to be distracted.

I noticed that I don't have enough things in the "relaxing" category that would reduce my inclination to be distracted.

2/ Think about your week & bucket all activities into a matrix: Time (A lot of time, Little time) vs. Importance (Very, Not very)

I extended "importance" to add Distracting & Relaxing as well.

This will make you reflect on your priorities in life. https://t.co/XNmb8EG6vL

1/ Here's a hack to replace that idle time where you often glance at your phone due to boredom & cycle through a bunch of distracting apps: Make a Time vs. Importance matrix. 

This idea was inspired by @NeilPasricha via https://t.co/TF9T50UwJY
@willmegson Back in mode: working on audio capture support to see if I can get a quick prototype done in the next 4 days.

Is there something better than Evernote where I can jot down notes & ideas really quickly that works on mobile + desktop? Must be lightweight & allow me organize the notes into groups of some sort.

It's time to move on...
@shl Ah then nbd — wasn’t sure if it was you thinking a lot about what to prioritize. That was my takeaway.
@shl You may not need a PM - just someone on the team who has good instincts.

@shl If it was me, I know my time is better spent talking to users, hearing the feedback, and trying to work on something that could bend the curve. I suspect moving tasks around is something you’re good at but isn’t the best use of your intuition & skills. I know it’s hard to let go.
@suushetty @willmegson We stream chrome from the cloud. That’s it.

@shl The main things that I feel are missing are:

(1) How do things add up to seeing the big picture?

(2) How can the team celebrate wins once the sum of the features conquer some important objective? How will anyone know? 

(3) Seems like you could remove yourself as the task mover

First real customer paid today actually using the product. Real problem: needs to open 50 tabs at once w/o Chrome crashing/freezing their computer to speedily qualify sales leads. To our own surprise we could handle it.

Thank you @willmegson! Now we have to actually stay up. 😩

@chibears7 Motion sickness often occurs due to jitter while reading text. Reduce jitter by increasing font size. 

I don’t get motion sick easily.

I literally sat in an Uber ride that was 17 min, started writing code, and before I knew it I was racing to finish something with 3 min left before arriving somewhere. 

Addendum: programming, incredibly,  also makes you want more time in otherwise boring circumstances.

text: @callmevlad 😕

@liamherbst29 I think it's really tough if you're a *young* first-time founder. You likely lack a clear community that you can trust & rely on because you're in the midst of building it. In which case, having a co-founder may be more optimal because you're going through it together.

@usshabb It has negatives too. You can easily have employees that contribute more than your co-founder later but lack the same incentive. It's tough because there's a premium placed on the risk at the beginning. When you start out, you don't know what you'll both become.

@MendesKristine Most founders come to me when they're not sure they want to be CEO anymore because it's something I gave up which was really hard--they can't tell their VCs yet. I think the best founder network dynamics are within small groups where everyone can trust each other.

@spakhm Later stage in a company, I think it's really challenging to rely on a single person like that. For me, I built a coping networking: wife, therapist, EA, CEO coach, co-founder, close friends, mom, etc.

Post leaving MP, I still have a lot of that same community.

I think previously I had the tendency to be more insular. Now, I love leaning on different people I can build trust with to help build something together.

It's hard to a/b this because I feel a bit more peace and mellowness than I did previously.

One of the surprising side effects I've experienced in not having a co-founder is more frequent collaboration.

I seek the advice/input of people I directly work with a lot more often: from recruiters to engineers to founder friends. And feel a lot happier working w/ a community.
@AlexGrinman Yes — your entire state of tabs and such are completely preserved.

We went from a user feeling like scrolling felt like Chrome on Windows in Bootcamp to 8.5/10 smooth native macOS scrolling after 2-3 weeks. 

Squashing our two biggest issues amongst users. 

We still have a long road ahead but major progress!

text: @GaryHatch @garrytan God damnit, Murphy!

My wife did not produce even a chuckle—generally laughs at all my bad jokes. 

😭
@alexangelj Feels a bit niche

@jasonfesta @benedictevans He is building something. @benedictevans creates more useful stuff than most people. Just because it’s not code doesn’t lessen its value. It’s his craft—no need to dismiss or diminish it.
@jasonfesta @benedictevans I think you’re misunderstanding his tweet. Typos are his bugs in his projects. He’s not pointing out a typo in my tweet.
@benedictevans Oh that’s the worst. You sit there reading this amazing thing you’ve written. Smug as hell—“damn I am genius”, you think. Then, that typo hits. 😳

Me: Ok, I am going to put this software through the wringer to find reproducible bugs to fix.

Bugs: Nah, not coming out. Taking a nap.

<later>

Me with users: Ok, thanks for signing up. Now, just click the icon & it should "just work."

Bugs: WHAT'S UP FAM. HOW WE DOING TODAY!

@corvinorum @stephkorey It took me a while to realize how much the stress of running a company wreaked havoc on my personality. I had never been in a high pressure situation to fully internalize its impact on me. I didn't have the coping mechanisms to close the gap on finding peace in that situation.

@corvinorum @stephkorey I’m not afraid of this: I’ve made lots of mistakes. I’ve done lots of things I wish I could redo while learning at my team’s expense & under stress. It’ll invariably happen again as I learn. I’m terribly sorry to my past & future teams. This doesn’t hurt me, if that was your goal

@secondcityy @stephkorey The straw man is you think that's my takeaway & only insight.

You read a version of the story - it is not a full account. I am not ready to make up mind based on a few cherry picked Slack messages. The full context matters in these situations even if you can't see how.

text: @JasonKimvc Ha! Truth!
Most of the above was accomplished with fewer than 30 employees ranging from engineering to customer support. They were some of the scrappiest, best people I’ve worked with.

During MP:

- We raised $500K (seed) during the recession 
- Later, we raised $1.25M with 70% of the above left 
- Later, we raised $10.25M with 80% of the total raised left 
- Later, we raised $65M with +$10M of profit in the bank ($22M)

We tried so hard to be scrappy.
@rashiq When you’re profitable & the possibility of it being a mistake is inconsequential in the long-run.

Just because you have a lot of money doesn’t mean you need to spend it. Save it. Wait till it’s time to grow & scale. Slowly building the right team & rhythm under constraints will benefit you in the long-run. Frivolous spending to appear successful just dilutes you. Be scrappy.

In year one you likely don’t need:
- A fancy office
- A full-time assistant 
- An office / ops mgr
- 2000+ sqft of office space 
- Fancy furniture 
- Lots of employees (> 10)
- Perfect design

What you do need: 
A product people love in spite of its flaws. 

The rest will come.

text: What many don’t know is that a major motivator in trying to make Mixpanel succeed was a desire to avoid going to back to ASU at all costs because I just wasn’t enjoying it. I felt I had chosen the wrong school. I wanted to make up for the mistake.
Sadly, I think I lost all my credits so I’d have to start over 😭

It’s late. I know all the India founders are up. 

Just so you know: my mom still wants me to finish college. 

(I dropped out a year before graduating)
@NupurDaveHere I find obsession as a positive trait when positively directed. That and I find leading a team of obsessives easier to work with.

@cyrux004 Maybe. It’s hard to say. I think it’s taken 1000s of interviews to feel like I can get good signal because I’ve asked so many people the same set of questions & received so many variants of answers/reactions. I suspect there’s an upper bound on the accuracy, unfortunately.

@anusheel123 We’re trying to be progressive in this area by offering candidates options to construct their own interview process that works well for them.

Most people choose the traditional interview loop due to time constraints if they actively have a job. I think that’ll be tough to break.

@andupotorac @ribas_artur @garrytan @NathanLatka You don’t have all the facts and it’s partially because it’s hidden from you. There’s a forum of many, many founders with unique stories all alleging similar aggressive behavior.

@SirSlaw_ Chatting about projects they’ve built or theoretically how other things people have built is a good starting point—in great depth. Curious engineers tend to be the most easily nerd sniped as a byproduct.
@KwatME I don’t see a strong correlation there.

I’ve been doing a lot of interviewing of engineers lately & the biggest defining difference between great ones and decent ones has mostly been whether there’s a natural, innate curiosity of how things work. Then, a desire to dive down the rabbit hole to seek the true answer.

@garrytan A fairly moronic thing someone can do is systematically harass a bunch of startup CEOs. Not because it's morally unrighteous but because it will likely become an oddly powerful network that will remember you harassing them.

You'll long-term get got many times over.

text: I am always impressed when backed into a corner, little runway left, and low in spirits due to a few consecutive duds how a couple of nobodies can create something people really want. It makes me wonder whether I was better off with $15K from YC & desperate to not go back "home."
@sachinrekhi I agree with @ilyasu — a definitive guide I feel would reduce the required thinking.
@VictorOspinaL 😂🤔

@sachinrekhi What it isn’t is:
- I need to update my valuation every 18 mo
- I need it to improve my brand with the press & future hires 
- I’ll go public one day
- I need to “take the market”
- My competitor has more money than me 
- Time to scale up sales rapidly we reached PMF

@sachinrekhi I follow old school advice which starts w/ the basis of questions: 
- Do I need more money to survive? - What would I do with it? 
- How much would I grow as a result? 
- How much dilution am I willing to take? 
- Which terms will I concede on? 
- Do I still need smart money?

text: TIL: "Carmack loves pizza. During his time at id Software, a pepperoni pizza would arrive for Carmack from Domino's Pizza almost every day, carried by the same delivery person for more than 15 yrs. Carmack had been such a regular customer that they still charge him 1995 prices."
@joelgascoigne @buffer I would not overly fixate much on net churn. Pure churn is a sign of troubles to come. Net masks reality.

@joelgascoigne @buffer It sounds like you'll flatline soon :(

The common strategy is:
1. Go further upmarket
2. Focus on annuals vs monthly
3. Improve the product rapidly (often means breaking how you built the process at present)
4. Re-think pricing/packaging

Takes 18-24 mo to course correct.

@joelgascoigne @buffer Your monthly revenue churn rate is 7.71%? If so, that's in the very dangerous territory. Have you tried modeling out what happens if the churn rate stays constant to see where the company's revenue growth flatlines? It can be really eye opening.
